title: Generate Color Palettes — get_palette
text: Generate palette k colors ggsci palettes, RColorbrewer  palettes custom color palettes. Useful extend RColorBrewer ggsci support colors.

title: Generate Color Palettes — get_palette
code: get_palette(palette = "default", k)

title: Generate Color Palettes — get_palette
text: palette Color palette. Allowed values include: Grey color palettes: "grey" "gray"; RColorBrewer palettes, see brewer.pal details section. Examples palette names include: "RdBu", "Blues", "Dark2", "Set2", ...; Custom color palettes. example, palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"); ggsci scientific journal palettes, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". k number colors generate.

title: Generate Color Palettes — get_palette
text: Returns vector color palettes.

title: Generate Color Palettes — get_palette
text: RColorBrewer palettes: display available color  palettes, type R:RColorBrewer::display.brewer.(). Color palette  names include:  Sequential palettes, suited ordered data  progress low high. Palette names include: Blues BuGn BuPu GnBu  Greens Greys Oranges OrRd PuBu PuBuGn PuRd Purples RdPu Reds YlGn YlGnBu  YlOrBr YlOrRd. Diverging palettes:Gradient colors. Names  include: BrBG PiYG PRGn PuOr RdBu RdGy RdYlBu RdYlGn Spectral. Qualitative palettes:  Best suited representing nominal  categorical data. Names include: Accent, Dark2, Paired, Pastel1, Pastel2,  Set1, Set2, Set3.

title: Generate Color Palettes — get_palette
code: data("iris") iris$Species2 <- factor(rep(c(1:10), each = 15))  # Generate a gradient of 10 colors ggscatter(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",  color = "Species2",  palette = get_palette(c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"), 10))   # Scatter plot with default color palette ggscatter(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",  color = "Species")   # RColorBrewer color palettes ggscatter(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",  color = "Species", palette = get_palette("Dark2", 3))   # ggsci color palettes ggscatter(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",  color = "Species", palette = get_palette("npg", 3))   # Custom color palette ggscatter(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",  color = "Species",  palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))   # Or use this ggscatter(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",  color = "Species",  palette = get_palette(c("#00AFBB", "#FC4E07"), 3))

what: Add Summary Statistics or a Geom onto a ggplot — ggadd
title: Add Summary Statistics or a Geom onto a ggplot — ggadd
text: Add summary statistics geometry onto ggplot.

title: Add Summary Statistics or a Geom onto a ggplot — ggadd
code: ggadd(   p,   add = NULL,   color = "black",   fill = "white",   group = 1,   width = 1,   shape = 19,   size = NULL,   alpha = 1,   jitter = 0.2,   seed = 123,   binwidth = NULL,   dotsize = size,   linetype = 1,   linewidth = size,   show.legend = NA,   error.plot = "pointrange",   ci = 0.95,   outliers = TRUE,   outlier.shape = 19,   data = NULL,   position = position_dodge(0.8),   p_geom = "" )

title: Add Summary Statistics or a Geom onto a ggplot — ggadd
text: p ggplot add character vector specifying plot elements added. Allowed values one combination : "none", "dotplot", "jitter", "boxplot", "point", "mean", "mean_se", "mean_sd", "mean_ci", "mean_range", "median", "median_iqr", "median_hilow", "median_q1q3", "median_mad", "median_range". color point outline color. fill fill color. Used error.plot = "crossbar". group grouping variable. Allowed values 1 (one group) character vector specifying name grouping variable. Used adding statistical summary per group. width numeric value 0 1 specifying bar box width. Example width = 0.8. Used error.plot one c("crossbar", "errorbar"). shape point shape. Allowed values can displayed using function show_point_shapes(). size numeric value [0-1] specifying point line size. alpha numeric value specifying fill color transparency. Value [0, 1], 0 full transparency 1 transparency. jitter numeric value specifying amount jittering. Used add contains "jitter". seed random seed make jitter reproducible. Default `123`. Useful need apply jitter twice, e.g., point corresponding label. random seed reset jittering. `NA`, seed initialized random value; makes sure two subsequent calls start different seed. Use NULL use current random seed also avoid resetting (behaviour ggplot 2.2.1 earlier). binwidth numeric value specifying bin width. use value 0 1 strong dense dotplot. example binwidth = 0.2. Used add contains "dotplot". dotsize size applied dotplot. linetype line type. linewidth numeric value [0-1] specifying line width. Used add contains "line" adding error bars. Default size. show.legend logical. layer included legends? NA, default, includes aesthetics mapped. FALSE never includes, TRUE always includes. can also named logical vector finely select aesthetics display. error.plot plot type used visualize error. Allowed values one c("pointrange", "linerange", "crossbar", "errorbar", "upper_errorbar", "lower_errorbar", "upper_pointrange", "lower_pointrange", "upper_linerange", "lower_linerange"). Default value "pointrange". ci percent range confidence interval (default 0.95). outliers logical. TRUE (default), outliers displayed boxplots. FALSE, outliers displayed. outlier.shape numeric value specifying shape outliers boxplots. Default 19 (filled circle). set NA, outliers displayed. data data.frame displayed. NULL, default, data inherited plot data specified call ggplot. position position adjustment, either string, result call position adjustment function. Used adjust position multiple groups. p_geom geometry main plot. Ex: p_geom = "geom_line". NULL, geometry extracted p. Used ggline().

title: Add Summary Statistics or a Geom onto a ggplot — ggadd
code: # Basic violin plot data("ToothGrowth") p <- ggviolin(ToothGrowth, x = "dose", y = "len", add = "none")  # Add mean +/- SD and jitter points p %>% ggadd(c("mean_sd", "jitter"), color = "dose")   # Add box plot p %>% ggadd(c("boxplot", "jitter"), color = "dose")

what: Adjust p-values Displayed on a GGPlot — ggadjust_pvalue
title: Adjust p-values Displayed on a GGPlot — ggadjust_pvalue
text: Adjust p-values produced geom_pwc() ggplot.  mainly useful using facet, p-values generally  computed adjusted panel without taking account panels.  case, one might want adjust p-values panels together.

title: Adjust p-values Displayed on a GGPlot — ggadjust_pvalue
code: ggadjust_pvalue(   p,   layer = NULL,   p.adjust.method = "holm",   label = "p.adj",   hide.ns = NULL,   symnum.args = list(),   p.format.style = "default",   p.digits = NULL,   p.leading.zero = NULL,   p.min.threshold = NULL,   p.decimal.mark = NULL,   signif.cutoffs = NULL,   signif.symbols = NULL,   ns.symbol = "ns",   use.four.stars = FALSE,   output = c("plot", "stat_test") )

title: Adjust p-values Displayed on a GGPlot — ggadjust_pvalue
text: p ggplot layer integer indicating statistical layer rank ggplot (order added plot). p.adjust.method method adjusting p values (see p.adjust).  impact situation, multiple pairwise tests performed; multiple grouping variables. Ignored specified method "tukey_hsd" "games_howell_test" come internal p adjustment method. Allowed values include "holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none". want adjust p value (recommended), use p.adjust.method = "none". label character string specifying label. Can : column containing label (e.g.: label = "p" label = "p.adj"), p p-value. possible values "p.signif", "p.adj.signif", "p.format", "p.format.signif", "p.adj.format". expression can formatted glue() package. example, specifying label = "Wilcoxon, p = \{p\}", expression {p} replaced value. combination plotmath expressions glue expressions. may want statistical parameter italic; example:label = "Wilcoxon, italic(p)= {p}" . hide.ns can logical value (TRUE FALSE) character vector ("p.adj" "p"). symnum.args list arguments pass function  symnum symbolic number coding p-values.  example, symnum.args = list(cutpoints = c(0, 0.0001, 0.001, 0.01,  0.05, Inf), symbols = c("****", "***", "**", "*",  "ns")). words, use following convention symbols indicating  statistical significance: ns: p > 0.05 *: p <= 0.05 **: p <= 0.01 ***: p <= 0.001 ****:  p <= 0.0001 Note: signif.cutoffs provided, takes precedence  symnum.args. p.format.style character string specifying p-value formatting style. One : "default" (backward compatible, uses scientific notation), "apa" (APA style, leading zero), "nejm" (NEJM style), "lancet" (Lancet style), "ama" (AMA style), "graphpad" (GraphPad style), "scientific" (scientific notation GWAS). See list_p_format_styles details. p.digits integer specifying number decimal places p-values. provided, overrides style default. p.leading.zero logical indicating whether include leading zero decimal point (e.g., "0.05" vs ".05"). provided, overrides style default. p.min.threshold numeric specifying minimum p-value display exactly. Values threshold shown "< threshold". provided, overrides style default. p.decimal.mark character string use decimal mark. NULL, uses getOption("OutDec"). signif.cutoffs numeric vector p-value cutoffs descending order assigning significance symbols. example, c(0.10, 0.05, 0.01) means p < 0.10 gets "*", p < 0.05 gets "**", p < 0.01 gets "***". Default NULL, uses package defaults. signif.symbols character vector symbols corresponding signif.cutoffs. NULL, auto-generated "*", "**", "***" ("****" use.four.stars = TRUE). ns.symbol character string non-significant results. Default "ns". Use "" (empty string) show nothing. use.four.stars logical. TRUE, allows four stars (****) significant level. Default FALSE. output character. Possible values one c("plot", "stat_test"). Default "plot".

title: Adjust p-values Displayed on a GGPlot — ggadjust_pvalue
code: # Data preparation #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: df <- ToothGrowth df$dose <- as.factor(df$dose) # Add a random grouping variable df$group <- factor(rep(c("grp1", "grp2"), 30)) head(df, 3) #>    len supp dose group #> 1  4.2   VC  0.5  grp1 #> 2 11.5   VC  0.5  grp2 #> 3  7.3   VC  0.5  grp1  # Boxplot: Two groups by panel #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: # Create a box plot bxp <- ggboxplot(   df, x = "supp", y = "len", fill = "#00AFBB",   facet.by = "dose" ) # Make facet and add p-values bxp <- bxp + geom_pwc(method = "t_test") bxp  # Adjust all p-values together after ggadjust_pvalue(   bxp, p.adjust.method = "bonferroni",   label = "{p.adj.format}{p.adj.signif}", hide.ns = TRUE )    # Boxplot: Three groups by panel #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: # Create a box plot bxp <- ggboxplot(   df, x = "dose", y = "len", fill = "#00AFBB",   facet.by = "supp" ) # Make facet and add p-values bxp <- bxp + geom_pwc(method = "t_test") bxp  # Adjust all p-values together after ggadjust_pvalue(   bxp, p.adjust.method = "bonferroni",   label = "{p.adj.format}{p.adj.signif}" )

title: Arrange Multiple ggplots — ggarrange
text: Arrange multiple ggplots page. Wrapper around   plot_grid(). Can arrange multiple ggplots   multiple pages, compared standard   plot_grid(). Can also create common unique legend   multiple plots.

title: Arrange Multiple ggplots — ggarrange
code: ggarrange(   ...,   plotlist = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   nrow = NULL,   labels = NULL,   label.x = 0,   label.y = 1,   hjust = -0.5,   vjust = 1.5,   font.label = list(size = 14, color = "black", face = "bold", family = NULL),   align = c("none", "h", "v", "hv"),   widths = 1,   heights = 1,   legend = NULL,   common.legend = FALSE,   legend.grob = NULL )

title: Arrange Multiple ggplots — ggarrange
text: ... list plots arranged grid. plots can either ggplot2 plot objects arbitrary gtables. plotlist (optional) list plots display. ncol (optional) number columns plot grid. nrow (optional) number rows plot grid. labels (optional) list labels added plots. can also set labels="AUTO" auto-generate upper-case labels labels="auto" auto-generate lower-case labels. label.x (optional) Single value vector x positions plot labels, relative subplot. Defaults 0 labels. (label placed way left plot.) label.y (optional) Single value vector y positions plot labels, relative subplot. Defaults 1 labels. (label placed way top plot.) hjust Adjusts horizontal position label. negative values move label right plot canvas. Can single value (applied labels) vector values (one label). Default -0.5. vjust Adjusts vertical position label. positive values move label plot canvas. Can single value (applied labels) vector values (one label). Default 1.5. font.label list arguments customizing labels. Allowed values combination following elements: size (e.g.: 14), face (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic"), color (e.g.: "red") family. example font.label = list(size = 14, face = "bold", color ="red"). align (optional) Specifies whether graphs grid horizontally ("h") vertically ("v") aligned. Options "none" (default), "hv" (align directions), "h", "v". widths (optional) numerical vector relative columns widths. example, two-column grid, widths = c(2, 1) make first column twice wide second column. heights widths column heights. legend character specifying legend position. Allowed values one c("top", "bottom", "left", "right", "none"). remove legend use legend = "none". common.legend logical value. Default FALSE. TRUE, common unique legend created arranged plots. legend.grob legend grob returned function get_legend(). provided, used common legend.

title: Arrange Multiple ggplots — ggarrange
text: return object class ggarrange, ggplot   list ggplot.

title: Arrange Multiple ggplots — ggarrange
text: Laszlo Erdey erdey.laszlo@econ.unideb.hu

title: Arrange Multiple ggplots — ggarrange
code: data("ToothGrowth") df <- ToothGrowth df$dose <- as.factor(df$dose)  # Create some plots # :::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: # Box plot bxp <- ggboxplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",     color = "dose", palette = "jco") # Dot plot dp <- ggdotplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",     color = "dose", palette = "jco") # Density plot dens <- ggdensity(df, x = "len", fill = "dose", palette = "jco")  # Arrange # :::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: ggarrange(bxp, dp, dens, ncol = 2, nrow = 2) #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`.  # Use a common legend for multiple plots ggarrange(bxp, dp,  common.legend = TRUE) #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`.

title: Ballon plot — ggballoonplot
text: Plot graphical matrix cell contains dot whose   size reflects relative magnitude corresponding component. Useful   visualize contingency table formed two categorical variables.

title: Ballon plot — ggballoonplot
code: ggballoonplot(   data,   x = NULL,   y = NULL,   size = "value",   facet.by = NULL,   size.range = c(1, 10),   shape = 21,   color = "black",   fill = "gray",   show.label = FALSE,   font.label = list(size = 12, color = "black"),   rotate.x.text = TRUE,   ggtheme = theme_minimal(),   ... )

title: Ballon plot — ggballoonplot
text: data data frame. Can : standard contingency table formed two categorical variables: data frame row names column names. categories first variable columns categories second variable rows. streched contingency table: data frame containing least three columns corresponding, respectively, (1) categories first variable, (2) categories second varible, (3) frequency value. case, specify argument x y function ggballoonplot() . x, y column names specifying, respectively, first second variable forming contingency table. Required data stretched contingency table. size point size. default, points size reflects relative magnitude value corresponding cell (size = "value"). Can also numeric (size = 4). facet.character vector, length 1 2, specifying grouping variables faceting plot multiple panels. data. size.range numeric vector length 2 specifies minimum maximum size plotting symbol. Default values size.range = c(1, 10). shape points shape. default value 21. Alternaive values include 22, 23, 24, 25. color point border line color. fill point fill color. Default "lightgray". Considered points 21 25. show.label logical. TRUE, show data cell values point labels. font.label vector length 3 indicating respectively size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") point labels. example font.label = c(14, "bold", "red"). specify size style, use font.label = c(14, "plain"). rotate.x.text logica. TRUE (default), rotate x axis text. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed function ggpar

title: Ballon plot — ggballoonplot
code: # Define color palette my_cols <- c("#0D0887FF", "#6A00A8FF", "#B12A90FF", "#E16462FF", "#FCA636FF", "#F0F921FF")  # Standard contingency table #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: # Read a contingency table: housetasks # Repartition of 13 housetasks in the couple data <- read.delim(   system.file("demo-data/housetasks.txt", package = "ggpubrplus"),   row.names = 1   ) data #>            Wife Alternating Husband Jointly #> Laundry     156          14       2       4 #> Main_meal   124          20       5       4 #> Dinner       77          11       7      13 #> Breakfeast   82          36      15       7 #> Tidying      53          11       1      57 #> Dishes       32          24       4      53 #> Shopping     33          23       9      55 #> Official     12          46      23      15 #> Driving      10          51      75       3 #> Finances     13          13      21      66 #> Insurance     8           1      53      77 #> Repairs       0           3     160       2 #> Holidays      0           1       6     153  # Basic ballon plot ggballoonplot(data)   # Change color and fill ggballoonplot(data, color = "#0073C2FF", fill = "#0073C2FF")    # Change color according to the value of table cells ggballoonplot(data, fill = "value")+    scale_fill_gradientn(colors = my_cols)   # Change the plotting symbol shape ggballoonplot(data, fill = "value",  shape = 23)+   gradient_fill(c("blue", "white", "red"))    # Set points size to 8, but change fill color by values # Sow labels ggballoonplot(data, fill = "value", color = "lightgray",               size = 10, show.label = TRUE)+   gradient_fill(c("blue", "white", "red"))   # Streched contingency table #:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::  # Create an Example Data Frame Containing Car x Color data carnames <- c("bmw","renault","mercedes","seat") carcolors <- c("red","white","silver","green") datavals <- round(rnorm(16, mean=100, sd=60),1) car_data <- data.frame(Car = rep(carnames,4),                    Color = rep(carcolors, c(4,4,4,4) ),                    Value=datavals )  car_data #>         Car  Color Value #> 1       bmw    red 110.6 #> 2   renault    red 114.6 #> 3  mercedes    red 197.4 #> 4      seat    red 106.7 #> 5       bmw  white  92.0 #> 6   renault  white -14.6 #> 7  mercedes  white  83.2 #> 8      seat  white  81.2 #> 9       bmw silver 164.0 #> 10  renault silver 104.2 #> 11 mercedes silver  61.7 #> 12     seat silver  97.0 #> 13      bmw  green  84.9 #> 14  renault  green 126.7 #> 15 mercedes  green 265.3 #> 16     seat  green 102.8  ggballoonplot(car_data, x = "Car", y = "Color",               size = "Value", fill = "Value") +    scale_fill_gradientn(colors = my_cols) +   guides(size = "none")    # Grouped frequency table #::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: data("Titanic") dframe <- as.data.frame(Titanic) head(dframe) #>   Class    Sex   Age Survived Freq #> 1   1st   Male Child       No    0 #> 2   2nd   Male Child       No    0 #> 3   3rd   Male Child       No   35 #> 4  Crew   Male Child       No    0 #> 5   1st Female Child       No    0 #> 6   2nd Female Child       No    0 ggballoonplot(  dframe, x = "Class", y = "Sex",  size = "Freq", fill = "Freq",  facet.by = c("Survived", "Age"),  ggtheme = theme_bw() )+   scale_fill_gradientn(colors = my_cols)   # Hair and Eye Color of Statistics Students data(HairEyeColor) ggballoonplot( as.data.frame(HairEyeColor),               x = "Hair", y = "Eye", size = "Freq",               ggtheme = theme_gray()) %>%  facet("Sex")

title: Bar plot — ggbarplot
text: Create bar plot.

title: Bar plot — ggbarplot
code: ggbarplot(   data,   x,   y,   combine = FALSE,   merge = FALSE,   color = "black",   fill = "white",   palette = NULL,   size = NULL,   width = NULL,   title = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   facet.by = NULL,   panel.labs = NULL,   short.panel.labs = TRUE,   select = NULL,   remove = NULL,   order = NULL,   add = "none",   add.params = list(),   error.plot = "errorbar",   label = FALSE,   lab.col = "black",   lab.size = 4,   lab.pos = c("out", "in"),   lab.vjust = NULL,   lab.hjust = NULL,   lab.nb.digits = NULL,   sort.val = c("none", "desc", "asc"),   sort.by.groups = TRUE,   top = Inf,   position = position_stack(),   ggtheme = theme_pubr(),   ... )

title: Bar plot — ggbarplot
text: data data frame x, y x y variables drawing. combine logical value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, create multi-panel plot combining plot y variables. merge logical character value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, merge multiple y variables plotting area. Allowed values include also "asis" (TRUE) "flip". merge = "flip", y variables used x tick labels x variable used grouping variable. color, fill outline fill colors. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". size Numeric value (e.g.: size = 1). change size points outlines. width numeric value 0 1 specifying box width. title plot main title. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab. facet.character vector, length 1 2, specifying grouping variables faceting plot multiple panels. data. panel.labs list one two character vectors modify facet panel labels. example, panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female")) specifies labels "sex" variable. two grouping variables, can use example panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female"), rx = c("Obs", "Lev", "Lev2") ). short.panel.labs logical value. Default TRUE. TRUE, create short labels panels omitting variable names; words panels labelled variable grouping levels. select character vector specifying items display. remove character vector specifying items remove plot. order character vector specifying order items. add character vector adding another plot element (e.g.: dot plot error bars). Allowed values one combination : "none", "dotplot", "jitter", "boxplot", "point", "mean", "mean_se", "mean_sd", "mean_ci", "mean_range", "median", "median_iqr", "median_hilow", "median_q1q3", "median_mad", "median_range"; see ?desc_statby details. add.params parameters (color, shape, size, fill, linetype) argument 'add'; e.g.: add.params = list(color = "red"). error.plot plot type used visualize error. Allowed values one c("pointrange", "linerange", "crossbar", "errorbar", "upper_errorbar", "lower_errorbar", "upper_pointrange", "lower_pointrange", "upper_linerange", "lower_linerange"). Default value "pointrange" "errorbar". Used add != "none" add contains one "mean_*" "med_*" "*" = sd, se, .... label specify whether add labels bar plot. Allowed values : logical value: TRUE, y values added labels bar plot character vector: Used text labels; must length y. lab.col, lab.size text color size labels. lab.pos character specifying position labels. Allowed values "" (outside) "" (inside). Ignored lab.vjust != NULL. lab.vjust numeric, vertical justification labels. Provide negative value (e.g.: -0.4) put labels outside bars positive value put labels inside (e.g.: 2). lab.hjust numeric, horizontal justification labels. lab.nb.digits integer indicating number decimal places (round) used. sort.val string specifying whether value sorted. Allowed values "none" (sorting), "asc" (ascending) "desc" (descending). sort..groups logical value. TRUE data sorted groups. Used sort.val != "none". top numeric value specifying number top elements shown. position position adjustment use data layer. can used various ways, including prevent overplotting improving display. position argument accepts following: result calling position function, position_jitter(). method allows passing extra arguments position. string naming position adjustment. give position string, strip function name position_ prefix. example, use position_jitter(), give position "jitter". information ways specify position, see layer position documentation. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed passed ggpar().

title: Bar plot — ggbarplot
text: plot can easily customized using function ggpar(). Read   ?ggpar changing: main title axis labels: main,   xlab, ylab axis limits: xlim, ylim (e.g.: ylim = c(0, 30)) axis   scales: xscale, yscale (e.g.: yscale = "log2") color palettes:   palette = "Dark2" palette = c("gray", "blue", "red") legend title,   labels position: legend = "right" plot orientation : orientation   = c("vertical", "horizontal", "reverse")

title: Bar plot — ggbarplot
code: # Data df <- data.frame(dose=c("D0.5", "D1", "D2"),    len=c(4.2, 10, 29.5)) print(df) #>   dose  len #> 1 D0.5  4.2 #> 2   D1 10.0 #> 3   D2 29.5  # Basic plot with label outsite # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++ ggbarplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",   label = TRUE, label.pos = "out")   # Change width ggbarplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len", width = 0.5)   # Change the plot orientation: horizontal ggbarplot(df, "dose", "len", orientation = "horiz")   # Change the default order of items ggbarplot(df, "dose", "len",    order = c("D2", "D1", "D0.5"))    # Change colors # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Change fill and outline color # add labels inside bars ggbarplot(df, "dose", "len",  fill = "steelblue", color = "steelblue",  label = TRUE, lab.pos = "in", lab.col = "white")   # Change colors by groups: dose # Use custom color palette  ggbarplot(df, "dose", "len", color = "dose",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))   # Change fill and outline colors by groups  ggbarplot(df, "dose", "len",    fill = "dose", color = "dose",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))    # Plot with multiple groups # +++++++++++++++++++++  # Create some data df2 <- data.frame(supp=rep(c("VC", "OJ"), each=3),    dose=rep(c("D0.5", "D1", "D2"),2),    len=c(6.8, 15, 33, 4.2, 10, 29.5)) print(df2) #>   supp dose  len #> 1   VC D0.5  6.8 #> 2   VC   D1 15.0 #> 3   VC   D2 33.0 #> 4   OJ D0.5  4.2 #> 5   OJ   D1 10.0 #> 6   OJ   D2 29.5  # Plot "len" by "dose" and change color by a second group: "supp" # Add labels inside bars ggbarplot(df2, "dose", "len",   fill = "supp", color = "supp", palette = "Paired",   label = TRUE, lab.col = "white", lab.pos = "in")   # Change position: Interleaved (dodged) bar plot ggbarplot(df2, "dose", "len",   fill = "supp", color = "supp", palette = "Paired",   label = TRUE,   position = position_dodge(0.9))   # Add points and errors # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Data: ToothGrowth data set we'll be used. df3 <- ToothGrowth head(df3, 10) #>     len supp dose #> 1   4.2   VC  0.5 #> 2  11.5   VC  0.5 #> 3   7.3   VC  0.5 #> 4   5.8   VC  0.5 #> 5   6.4   VC  0.5 #> 6  10.0   VC  0.5 #> 7  11.2   VC  0.5 #> 8  11.2   VC  0.5 #> 9   5.2   VC  0.5 #> 10  7.0   VC  0.5  # It can be seen that for each group we have # different values ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len")   # Visualize the mean of each group ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean")   # Add error bars: mean_se # (other values include: mean_sd, mean_ci, median_iqr, ....) # Add labels ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean_se", label = TRUE, lab.vjust = -1.6)   # Use only "upper_errorbar" ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean_se", error.plot = "upper_errorbar")   # Change error.plot to "pointrange" ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean_se", error.plot = "pointrange")   # Add jitter points and errors (mean_se) ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = c("mean_se", "jitter"))   # Add dot and errors (mean_se) ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = c("mean_se", "dotplot")) #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`.   # Multiple groups with error bars and jitter point ggbarplot(df3, x = "dose", y = "len", color = "supp",  add = "mean_se", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"),  position = position_dodge())

title: Box plot — ggboxplot
text: Create box plot points. Box plots display group  numerical data quartiles.

title: Box plot — ggboxplot
code: ggboxplot(   data,   x,   y,   combine = FALSE,   merge = FALSE,   color = "black",   fill = "white",   palette = NULL,   title = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   bxp.errorbar = FALSE,   bxp.errorbar.width = 0.4,   facet.by = NULL,   panel.labs = NULL,   short.panel.labs = TRUE,   linetype = "solid",   size = NULL,   linewidth = NULL,   width = 0.7,   notch = FALSE,   outliers = TRUE,   outlier.shape = 19,   select = NULL,   remove = NULL,   order = NULL,   add = "none",   add.params = list(),   error.plot = "pointrange",   label = NULL,   font.label = list(size = 11, color = "black"),   label.select = NULL,   repel = FALSE,   label.rectangle = FALSE,   ggtheme = theme_pubr(),   ... )

title: Box plot — ggboxplot
text: data data frame x character string containing name x variable. y character vector containing one variables plot combine logical value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, create multi-panel plot combining plot y variables. merge logical character value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, merge multiple y variables plotting area. Allowed values include also "asis" (TRUE) "flip". merge = "flip", y variables used x tick labels x variable used grouping variable. color outline color. fill fill color. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". title plot main title. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab. bxp.errorbar logical value. TRUE, shows error bars box plots. bxp.errorbar.width numeric value specifying width box plot error bars. Default 0.4. facet.character vector, length 1 2, specifying grouping variables faceting plot multiple panels. data. panel.labs list one two character vectors modify facet panel labels. example, panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female")) specifies labels "sex" variable. two grouping variables, can use example panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female"), rx = c("Obs", "Lev", "Lev2") ). short.panel.labs logical value. Default TRUE. TRUE, create short labels panels omitting variable names; words panels labelled variable grouping levels. linetype line types. size Numeric value (e.g.: size = 1). change size points outlines. linewidth constant value specifying line width. width numeric value 0 1 specifying box width. notch FALSE (default) make standard box plot. TRUE, make notched box plot. Notches used compare groups; notches two boxes overlap, suggests medians significantly different. outliers Whether display (TRUE) discard (FALSE) outliers plot. Hiding discarding outliers can useful , example, raw data points need displayed top boxplot. discarding outliers, axis limits adapt box whiskers , full data range. outliers need hidden axes needs show full data range, please use outlier.shape = NA instead. outlier.shape point shape outlier. Default 19. hide outlier, specify outlier.shape = NA. jitter added, outliers automatically hidden. select character vector specifying items display. remove character vector specifying items remove plot. order character vector specifying order items. add character vector adding another plot element (e.g.: dot plot error bars). Allowed values one combination : "none", "dotplot", "jitter", "boxplot", "point", "mean", "mean_se", "mean_sd", "mean_ci", "mean_range", "median", "median_iqr", "median_hilow", "median_q1q3", "median_mad", "median_range"; see ?desc_statby details. add.params parameters (color, shape, size, fill, linetype) argument 'add'; e.g.: add.params = list(color = "red"). error.plot plot type used visualize error. Allowed values one c("pointrange", "linerange", "crossbar", "errorbar", "upper_errorbar", "lower_errorbar", "upper_pointrange", "lower_pointrange", "upper_linerange", "lower_linerange"). Default value "pointrange" "errorbar". Used add != "none" add contains one "mean_*" "med_*" "*" = sd, se, .... label name column containing point labels. Can also character vector length = nrow(data). font.label list can contain combination following elements: size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") labels. example font.label = list(size = 14, face = "bold", color ="red"). specify size style, use font.label = list(size = 14, face = "plain"). label.select can two formats: character vector specifying labels show. list containing one combination following components: top.top.: display labels  top /points. example, label.select = list(top.= 10, top.= 4). criteria: filter, example, x y variabes values, use : label.select = list(criteria = "`y` > 2 & `y` < 5 & `x` %% c('', 'B')"). repel logical value, whether use ggrepel avoid overplotting text labels . label.rectangle logical value. TRUE, add rectangle underneath text, making easier read. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed geom_boxplot, ggpar facet.

title: Box plot — ggboxplot
text: plot can easily customized using function ggpar(). Read  ?ggpar changing: main title axis labels: main, xlab,  ylab axis limits: xlim, ylim (e.g.: ylim = c(0, 30)) axis  scales: xscale, yscale (e.g.: yscale = "log2") color palettes: palette  = "Dark2" palette = c("gray", "blue", "red") legend title, labels  position: legend = "right" plot orientation : orientation =  c("vertical", "horizontal", "reverse")

title: Box plot — ggboxplot
text: Suggested values one  c("dotplot", "jitter").

title: Box plot — ggboxplot
code: # Load data data("ToothGrowth") df <- ToothGrowth  # Basic plot # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # width: change box plots width ggboxplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len", width = 0.8)   # Change orientation: horizontal ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len", orientation = "horizontal")   # Notched box plot ggboxplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",    notch = TRUE)   # Add dots # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ ggboxplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",    add = "dotplot") #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`.   # Add jitter points and change the shape by groups ggboxplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",    add = "jitter", shape = "dose")    # Select and order items # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Select which items to display: "0.5" and "2" ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len",    select = c("0.5", "2"))   # Change the default order of items ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len",    order = c("2", "1", "0.5"))    # Change colors # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Change outline and fill colors  ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len",    color = "black", fill = "gray")   # Change outline colors by groups: dose # Use custom color palette # Add jitter points and change the shape by groups  ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len",     color = "dose", palette =c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"),     add = "jitter", shape = "dose")   # Change fill color by groups: dose  ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len",      fill = "dose", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))    # Box plot with multiple groups # +++++++++++++++++++++ # fill or color box plot by a second group : "supp" ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len", color = "supp",  palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))

title: Density plot — ggdensity
code: # Create some data format set.seed(1234) wdata = data.frame(    sex = factor(rep(c("F", "M"), each=200)),    weight = c(rnorm(200, 55), rnorm(200, 58)))  head(wdata, 4) #>   sex   weight #> 1   F 53.79293 #> 2   F 55.27743 #> 3   F 56.08444 #> 4   F 52.65430  # Basic density plot  # Add mean line and marginal rug ggdensity(wdata, x = "weight", fill = "lightgray",    add = "mean", rug = TRUE) #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the ggpubrplus package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/erdeyl/ggpubrplus/issues>. #> Warning: Ignoring empty aesthetic: `size`.   # Change outline colors by groups ("sex") # Use custom palette ggdensity(wdata, x = "weight",    add = "mean", rug = TRUE,    color = "sex", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))    # Change outline and fill colors by groups ("sex") # Use custom palette ggdensity(wdata, x = "weight",    add = "mean", rug = TRUE,    color = "sex", fill = "sex",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))

title: Donut chart — ggdonutchart
code: # Data: Create some data # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  df <- data.frame(  group = c("Male", "Female", "Child"),   value = c(25, 25, 50))  head(df) #>    group value #> 1   Male    25 #> 2 Female    25 #> 3  Child    50   # Basic pie charts # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  ggdonutchart(df, "value", label = "group")    # Change color # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Change fill color by group # set line color to white # Use custom color palette  ggdonutchart(df, "value", label = "group",       fill = "group", color = "white",        palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07") )    # Change label # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Show group names and value as labels labs <- paste0(df$group, " (", df$value, "%)") ggdonutchart(df, "value", label = labs,    fill = "group", color = "white",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))   # Change the position and font color of labels ggdonutchart(df, "value", label = labs,    lab.pos = "in", lab.font = "white",    fill = "group", color = "white",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))

title: Cleveland's Dot Plots — ggdotchart
code: # Load data data("mtcars") df <- mtcars df$cyl <- as.factor(df$cyl) df$name <- rownames(df) head(df[, c("wt", "mpg", "cyl")], 3) #>                  wt  mpg cyl #> Mazda RX4     2.620 21.0   6 #> Mazda RX4 Wag 2.875 21.0   6 #> Datsun 710    2.320 22.8   4  # Basic plot ggdotchart(df, x = "name", y ="mpg",   ggtheme = theme_bw())   # Change colors by  group cyl ggdotchart(df, x = "name", y = "mpg",    group = "cyl", color = "cyl",    palette = c('#999999','#E69F00','#56B4E9'),    rotate = TRUE,    sorting = "descending",    ggtheme = theme_bw(),    y.text.col = TRUE )    # Plot with multiple groups # +++++++++++++++++++++ # Create some data df2 <- data.frame(supp=rep(c("VC", "OJ"), each=3),                  dose=rep(c("D0.5", "D1", "D2"),2),                  len=c(6.8, 15, 33, 4.2, 10, 29.5)) print(df2) #>   supp dose  len #> 1   VC D0.5  6.8 #> 2   VC   D1 15.0 #> 3   VC   D2 33.0 #> 4   OJ D0.5  4.2 #> 5   OJ   D1 10.0 #> 6   OJ   D2 29.5  ggdotchart(df2, x = "dose", y = "len",           color = "supp", size = 3,           add = "segment",           add.params = list(color = "lightgray", linewidth = 1.5),           position = position_dodge(0.3),           palette = "jco",           ggtheme = theme_pubclean() )

code: # Data: ToothGrowth data set we'll be used. df<- ToothGrowth head(df, 10) #>     len supp dose #> 1   4.2   VC  0.5 #> 2  11.5   VC  0.5 #> 3   7.3   VC  0.5 #> 4   5.8   VC  0.5 #> 5   6.4   VC  0.5 #> 6  10.0   VC  0.5 #> 7  11.2   VC  0.5 #> 8  11.2   VC  0.5 #> 9   5.2   VC  0.5 #> 10  7.0   VC  0.5  # Plot mean_se ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len")    # Change desc_stat to mean_sd # (other values include: mean_sd, mean_ci, median_iqr, ....) # Add labels ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",  desc_stat = "mean_sd")   # Change error.plot to "errorbar" and add mean point # Visualize the mean of each group ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean", error.plot = "errorbar")   # Horizontal plot ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean", error.plot = "errorbar",  orientation = "horizontal")    # Change error.plot to "crossbar" ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",  error.plot = "crossbar", width = 0.5)    # Add jitter points and errors (mean_se) ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "jitter")   # Add dot and errors (mean_se) ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "dotplot") #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`.   # Multiple groups with error bars and jitter point ggerrorplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len",  color = "supp", palette = "Paired",  error.plot = "pointrange",  position = position_dodge(0.5))

title: Histogram plot — gghistogram
text: data data frame x variable drawn. y one "density" "count". combine logical value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, create multi-panel plot combining plot y variables. merge logical character value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, merge multiple y variables plotting area. Allowed values include also "asis" (TRUE) "flip". merge = "flip", y variables used x tick labels x variable used grouping variable. weight variable name available input data creating weighted histogram. color, fill histogram line color fill color. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". size Numeric value (e.g.: size = 1). change size points outlines. linetype line type. See show_line_types. linewidth numeric value specifying line width. alpha numeric value specifying fill color transparency. Value [0, 1], 0 full transparency 1 transparency. bins Number bins. Defaults 30. binwidth numeric value specifying bin width. use value 0 1 strong dense dotplot. example binwidth = 0.2. title plot main title. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab. facet.character vector, length 1 2, specifying grouping variables faceting plot multiple panels. data. panel.labs list one two character vectors modify facet panel labels. example, panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female")) specifies labels "sex" variable. two grouping variables, can use example panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female"), rx = c("Obs", "Lev", "Lev2") ). short.panel.labs logical value. Default TRUE. TRUE, create short labels panels omitting variable names; words panels labelled variable grouping levels. add allowed values one "mean" "median" (adding mean median line, respectively). add.params parameters (color, size, linetype) argument 'add'; e.g.: add.params = list(color = "red"). rug logical value. TRUE, add marginal rug. add_density logical value. TRUE, add density curves. label name column containing point labels. Can also character vector length = nrow(data). font.label list can contain combination following elements: size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") labels. example font.label = list(size = 14, face = "bold", color ="red"). specify size style, use font.label = list(size = 14, face = "plain"). label.select can two formats: character vector specifying labels show. list containing one combination following components: top.top.: display labels  top /points. example, label.select = list(top.= 10, top.= 4). criteria: filter, example, x y variabes values, use : label.select = list(criteria = "`y` > 2 & `y` < 5 & `x` %% c('', 'B')"). repel logical value, whether use ggrepel avoid overplotting text labels . label.rectangle logical value. TRUE, add rectangle underneath text, making easier read. position Position adjustment, either string, result call position adjustment function. Allowed values include "identity", "stack", "dodge". ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed geom_histogram ggpar.

title: Histogram plot — gghistogram
code: # Create some data format set.seed(1234) wdata = data.frame(    sex = factor(rep(c("F", "M"), each=200)),    weight = c(rnorm(200, 55), rnorm(200, 58)))  head(wdata, 4) #>   sex   weight #> 1   F 53.79293 #> 2   F 55.27743 #> 3   F 56.08444 #> 4   F 52.65430  # Basic density plot # Add mean line and marginal rug gghistogram(wdata, x = "weight", fill = "lightgray",    add = "mean", rug = TRUE) #> Warning: Ignoring empty aesthetic: `size`.   # Change outline colors by groups ("sex") # Use custom color palette gghistogram(wdata, x = "weight",    add = "mean", rug = TRUE,    color = "sex", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))   # Change outline and fill colors by groups ("sex") # Use custom color palette gghistogram(wdata, x = "weight",    add = "mean", rug = TRUE,    color = "sex", fill = "sex",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))     # Combine histogram and density plots gghistogram(wdata, x = "weight",    add = "mean", rug = TRUE,    fill = "sex", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"),    add_density = TRUE)   # Weighted histogram gghistogram(iris, x = "Sepal.Length", weight = "Petal.Length")

title: Line plot — ggline
text: plot can easily customized using function ggpar(). Read   ?ggpar changing: main title axis labels: main,   xlab, ylab axis limits: xlim, ylim (e.g.: ylim = c(0, 30)) axis   scales: xscale, yscale (e.g.: yscale = "log2") color palettes:   palette = "Dark2" palette = c("gray", "blue", "red") legend title,   labels position: legend = "right" plot orientation : orientation   = c("vertical", "horizontal", "reverse")

title: Line plot — ggline
code: # Data df <- data.frame(dose=c("D0.5", "D1", "D2"),    len=c(4.2, 10, 29.5)) print(df) #>   dose  len #> 1 D0.5  4.2 #> 2   D1 10.0 #> 3   D2 29.5  # Basic plot # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++ ggline(df, x = "dose", y = "len")    # Plot with multiple groups # +++++++++++++++++++++  # Create some data df2 <- data.frame(supp=rep(c("VC", "OJ"), each=3),    dose=rep(c("D0.5", "D1", "D2"),2),    len=c(6.8, 15, 33, 4.2, 10, 29.5)) print(df2) #>   supp dose  len #> 1   VC D0.5  6.8 #> 2   VC   D1 15.0 #> 3   VC   D2 33.0 #> 4   OJ D0.5  4.2 #> 5   OJ   D1 10.0 #> 6   OJ   D2 29.5  # Plot "len" by "dose" and # Change line types and point shapes by a second groups: "supp" ggline(df2, "dose", "len",   linetype = "supp", shape = "supp")    # Change colors # +++++++++++++++++++++  # Change color by group: "supp" # Use custom color palette ggline(df2, "dose", "len",    linetype = "supp", shape = "supp",    color = "supp", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))    # Add points and errors # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Data: ToothGrowth data set we'll be used. df3 <- ToothGrowth head(df3, 10) #>     len supp dose #> 1   4.2   VC  0.5 #> 2  11.5   VC  0.5 #> 3   7.3   VC  0.5 #> 4   5.8   VC  0.5 #> 5   6.4   VC  0.5 #> 6  10.0   VC  0.5 #> 7  11.2   VC  0.5 #> 8  11.2   VC  0.5 #> 9   5.2   VC  0.5 #> 10  7.0   VC  0.5  # It can be seen that for each group we have # different values ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len")   # Visualize the mean of each group ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean")   # Add error bars: mean_se # (other values include: mean_sd, mean_ci, median_iqr, ....) # Add labels ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len", add = "mean_se")   # Change error.plot to "pointrange" ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = "mean_se", error.plot = "pointrange")   # Add jitter points and errors (mean_se) ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = c("mean_se", "jitter"))   # Add dot and errors (mean_se) ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = c("mean_se", "dotplot"), color = "steelblue") #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`.   # Add violin and errors (mean_se) ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len",  add = c("mean_se", "violin"), color = "steelblue")   # Multiple groups with error bars # ++++++++++++++++++++++  ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len", color = "supp",  add = "mean_se", palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))   # Add jitter ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len", color = "supp",  add = c("mean_se", "jitter"), palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800"))   # Add dot plot ggline(df3, x = "dose", y = "len", color = "supp",  add = c("mean_se", "dotplot"), palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800")) #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`.

what: MA-plot from means and log fold changes — ggmaplot
title: MA-plot from means and log fold changes — ggmaplot
text: Make MA-plot scatter plot log2 fold changes (M,  y-axis) versus average expression signal (, x-axis). M  = log2(x/y) = (log2(x) + log2(y))/2 = log2(xy)*1/2, x  y respectively mean two groups compared.

title: MA-plot from means and log fold changes — ggmaplot
code: ggmaplot(   data,   fdr = 0.05,   fc = 1.5,   genenames = NULL,   detection_call = NULL,   size = NULL,   alpha = 1,   seed = 42,   font.label = c(12, "plain", "black"),   label.rectangle = FALSE,   palette = c("#B31B21", "#1465AC", "darkgray"),   top = 15,   select.top.method = c("padj", "fc"),   label.select = NULL,   main = NULL,   xlab = "Log2 mean expression",   ylab = "Log2 fold change",   ggtheme = theme_classic(),   ... )

title: MA-plot from means and log fold changes — ggmaplot
text: data object class DESeqResults, get_diff, DE_Results, matrix  data frame containing columns baseMean (baseMeanLog2),  log2FoldChange, padj. Rows genes. Two possible formats accepted input data: 1/  baseMean | log2FoldChange | padj. typical output  DESeq2 pipeline. , use log2(baseMean) x-axis variable. 2/ baseMeanLog2 | log2FoldChange | padj. , baseMeanLog2  assumed mean logged values; use x-axis  variable without transformation. real MA plot.  words, average two log-scales values: = (log2(x) +  log2(y))/2 = log2(xy)*1/2 Terminology:  baseMean: mean expression genes two groups. log2FoldChange: log2 fold changes group 2 compared group 1 padj: adjusted p-value used statiscal test. fdr Accepted false discovery rate considering genes differentially expressed. fc fold change threshold. genes fold change >= fc padj <= fdr considered significantly differentially expressed. genenames character vector length nrow(data) specifying gene names corresponding row. Used point labels. detection_call numeric vector length = nrow(data), specifying genes expressed (value = 1) (value = 0). example detection_call = c(1, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1). Default NULL. detection_call column available data, used. size points size. alpha numeric value betwenn 0 1 specifying point alpha controlling transparency. example, use alpha = 0.5. seed Random seed passed set.seed. NA, set.seed called. Default 42 reproducibility. font.label vector length 3 indicating respectively size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") point labels. example font.label = c(14, "bold", "red"). label.rectangle logical value. TRUE, add rectangle underneath text, making easier read. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". top number top genes shown plot. Use top = 0 hide gene labels. select.top.method methods used selecting top genes. Allowed values include "padj" "fc" selecting adjusted p values fold changes, respectively. label.select character vector specifying labels show. main plot main title. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed ggpar.

title: MA-plot from means and log fold changes — ggmaplot
code: data(diff_express)  # Default plot ggmaplot(diff_express, main = expression("Group 1" %->% "Group 2"),    fdr = 0.05, fc = 2, size = 0.4,    palette = c("#B31B21", "#1465AC", "darkgray"),    genenames = as.vector(diff_express$name),    legend = "top", top = 20,    font.label = c("bold", 11),    font.legend = "bold",    font.main = "bold",    ggtheme = ggplot2::theme_minimal())   # Add rectangle around labels ggmaplot(diff_express, main = expression("Group 1" %->% "Group 2"),    fdr = 0.05, fc = 2, size = 0.4,    palette = c("#B31B21", "#1465AC", "darkgray"),    genenames = as.vector(diff_express$name),    legend = "top", top = 20,    font.label = c("bold", 11), label.rectangle = TRUE,    font.legend = "bold",    font.main = "bold",    ggtheme = ggplot2::theme_minimal())   # Select specific genes to show # set top = 0, then specify genes using label.select argument ggmaplot(diff_express, main = expression("Group 1" %->% "Group 2"),          fdr = 0.05, fc = 2, size = 0.4,          genenames = as.vector(diff_express$name),          ggtheme = ggplot2::theme_minimal(),          top = 0, label.select = c("BUB1", "CD83") )

code: ggpaired(   data,   cond1,   cond2,   x = NULL,   y = NULL,   id = NULL,   color = "black",   fill = "white",   palette = NULL,   width = 0.5,   point.size = 1.2,   line.size = 0.5,   line.color = "black",   linetype = "solid",   title = NULL,   xlab = "Condition",   ylab = "Value",   facet.by = NULL,   panel.labs = NULL,   short.panel.labs = TRUE,   label = NULL,   font.label = list(size = 11, color = "black"),   label.select = NULL,   repel = FALSE,   label.rectangle = FALSE,   ggtheme = theme_pubr(),   ... )

title: Plot Paired Data — ggpaired
text: data data frame cond1 variable name corresponding first condition. cond2 variable name corresponding second condition. x, y x y variables, x grouping variable y contains values group. Considered cond1 cond2 missing. id variable name corresponding paired samples' id. Used connect paired points lines. color points box plot colors. color conditions, use color = "condition". fill box plot fill color. change fill color conditions, use fill = "condition". palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". width box plot width. point.size, line.size point line size, respectively. line.color line color. linetype line type. title plot main title. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab. facet.character vector, length 1 2, specifying grouping variables faceting plot multiple panels. data. panel.labs list one two character vectors modify facet panel labels. example, panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female")) specifies labels "sex" variable. two grouping variables, can use example panel.labs = list(sex = c("Male", "Female"), rx = c("Obs", "Lev", "Lev2") ). short.panel.labs logical value. Default TRUE. TRUE, create short labels panels omitting variable names; words panels labelled variable grouping levels. label name column containing point labels. Can also character vector length = nrow(data). font.label list can contain combination following elements: size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") labels. example font.label = list(size = 14, face = "bold", color ="red"). specify size style, use font.label = list(size = 14, face = "plain"). label.select can two formats: character vector specifying labels show. list containing one combination following components: top.top.: display labels  top /points. example, label.select = list(top.= 10, top.= 4). criteria: filter, example, x y variabes values, use : label.select = list(criteria = "`y` > 2 & `y` < 5 & `x` %% c('', 'B')"). repel logical value, whether use ggrepel avoid overplotting text labels . label.rectangle logical value. TRUE, add rectangle underneath text, making easier read. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed passed ggpar().

title: Plot Paired Data — ggpaired
code: # Example 1 #:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: before <-c(200.1, 190.9, 192.7, 213, 241.4, 196.9, 172.2, 185.5, 205.2, 193.7) after <-c(392.9, 393.2, 345.1, 393, 434, 427.9, 422, 383.9, 392.3, 352.2)  d <- data.frame(before = before, after = after) ggpaired(d, cond1 = "before", cond2 = "after",     fill = "condition", palette = "jco")   # Example 2 #:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: ggpaired(ToothGrowth, x = "supp", y = "len",  color = "supp", line.color = "gray", line.size = 0.4,  palette = "npg")

title: Graphical parameters — ggpar
code: ggpar(   p,   palette = NULL,   gradient.cols = NULL,   main = NULL,   submain = NULL,   caption = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   font.main = NULL,   font.submain = NULL,   font.x = NULL,   font.y = NULL,   font.caption = NULL,   font.title = NULL,   font.subtitle = NULL,   font.family = "",   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   xscale = c("none", "log2", "log10", "sqrt"),   yscale = c("none", "log2", "log10", "sqrt"),   format.scale = FALSE,   legend = NULL,   legend.title = NULL,   font.legend = NULL,   ticks = TRUE,   tickslab = TRUE,   font.tickslab = NULL,   font.xtickslab = font.tickslab,   font.ytickslab = font.tickslab,   x.text.angle = NULL,   y.text.angle = NULL,   xtickslab.rt = x.text.angle,   ytickslab.rt = y.text.angle,   xticks.by = NULL,   yticks.by = NULL,   rotate = FALSE,   orientation = c("vertical", "horizontal", "reverse"),   ggtheme = NULL,   ... )

title: Graphical parameters — ggpar
text: p object class ggplot list ggplots palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". Can also numeric vector length(groups); case basic color palette created using function palette. gradient.cols vector colors use n-colour gradient. Allowed values include brewer ggsci color palettes. main plot main title. submain, subtitle plot subtitle. caption plot caption. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab. title plot main title. font.main, font.submain, font.caption, font.x, font.y vector length 3 indicating respectively size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") main title, subtitle, caption, xlab ylab, respectively. example font.x = c(14, "bold", "red"). Use font.x = 14, change font size; use font.x = "bold", change font face. font.title, font.subtitle alias font.submain font.submain, respectively. font.family character vector specifying font family. xlim, ylim numeric vector length 2, specifying  x y axis limits (minimum maximum), respectively. e.g.: ylim = c(0, 50). xscale, yscale x y axis scale, respectively. Allowed values one c("none", "log2", "log10", "sqrt"); e.g.: yscale="log2". format.scale logical value. TRUE, axis tick mark labels formatted xscale yscale = "log2" "log10". legend character specifying legend position. Allowed values one c("top", "bottom", "left", "right", "none"). remove legend use legend = "none". Legend position can also specified using numeric vector c(x, y); see details section. legend.title legend title, e.g.: legend.title = "Species". Can also list, legend.title = list(color = "Species", linetype = "Species", shape = "Species"). font.legend legend text font style; e.g.: font.legend = c(10, "plain", "black"). ticks logical value. Default TRUE. FALSE, hide axis tick marks. tickslab logical value. Default TRUE. FALSE, hide axis tick labels. font.tickslab, font.xtickslab, font.ytickslab Font style (size, face, color) tick labels, e.g.: c(14, "bold", "red"). x.text.angle, y.text.angle Numeric value specifying rotation angle x y axis tick labels, respectively. Default value NULL. vertical x axis texts use x.text.angle = 90. xtickslab.rt, ytickslab.rt x.text.angle y.text.angle, respectively. deprecated near future. xticks., yticks.numeric value controlling x y axis breaks, respectively. example, yticks.= 5, tick mark shown every 5. Default value NULL. rotate logical value. TRUE, rotate graph setting plot orientation horizontal. orientation change orientation plot. Allowed values one c( "vertical", "horizontal", "reverse"). Partial match allowed. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... used

title: Graphical parameters — ggpar
code: # Load data data("ToothGrowth") df <- ToothGrowth  # Basic box plot # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++  p <- ggboxplot(df, x = "dose", y = "len")  # Change the plot orientation: horizontal ggpar(p, orientation = "horiz")     # Change main title and axis labels  # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++   ggpar(p,    main = "Plot of length \n by dose",    xlab = "Dose (mg)", ylab = "Length")    # Title font styles: 'plain', 'italic', 'bold', 'bold.italic'  ggpar(p,    main = "Length by dose",    font.main = c(14,"bold.italic", "red"),    font.x = c(14, "bold", "#2E9FDF"),    font.y = c(14, "bold", "#E7B800"))    # Hide axis labels  ggpar(p, xlab = FALSE, ylab = FALSE)    # Change colors # ++++++++++++++++++++++  # Change outline colors by groups: dose  p2 <- ggboxplot(df, "dose", "len", color = "dose")  p2   # Use custom color palette ggpar(p2, palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))   # Use brewer palette ggpar(p2, palette = "Dark2" )   # Use grey palette ggpar(p2, palette = "grey")   # Use scientific journal palette from ggsci package ggpar(p2, palette = "npg") # nature   # Axis ticks, limits, scales # +++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Axis ticks labels and rotation ggpar(p,  font.tickslab = c(14,"bold", "#993333"),  xtickslab.rt = 45, ytickslab.rt = 45)  # Hide axis ticks and tick labels ggpar(p, ticks = FALSE, tickslab = FALSE)   # Axis limits ggpar(p, ylim = c(0, 50))   # Axis scale ggpar(p, yscale = "log2")   # Format axis scale ggpar(p, yscale = "log2", format.scale = TRUE)   # Legends # ++++++++++++++++++ # Change legend position and title ggpar(p2,  legend = "right", legend.title = "Dose (mg)",  font.legend = c(10, "bold", "red"))

code: # Density plot density.p <- ggdensity(iris, x = "Sepal.Length",                       fill = "Species", palette = "jco")  # Text plot text <- paste("iris data set gives the measurements in cm",              "of the variables sepal length and width",              "and petal length and width, respectively,",              "for 50 flowers from each of 3 species of iris.",              "The species are Iris setosa, versicolor, and virginica.", sep = " ") text.p <- ggparagraph(text, face = "italic", size = 12)  # Arrange the plots on the same page ggarrange(density.p, text.p,          ncol = 1, nrow = 2,          heights = c(1, 0.3))

Increase decrease value see effect. lab.font vector length 3 indicating respectively size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") label font. example lab.font= c(4, "bold", "red"). font.family character vector specifying font family. color, fill outline fill colors. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". size Numeric value (e.g.: size = 1). change size points outlines. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed passed ggpar().

title: Pie chart — ggpie
text: plot can easily customized using function ggpar(). Read  ?ggpar changing: main title axis labels: main, xlab,  ylab axis limits: xlim, ylim (e.g.: ylim = c(0, 30)) axis  scales: xscale, yscale (e.g.: yscale = "log2") color palettes: palette  = "Dark2" palette = c("gray", "blue", "red") legend title, labels  position: legend = "right" plot orientation : orientation =  c("vertical", "horizontal", "reverse")

title: Pie chart — ggpie
code: # Data: Create some data # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  df <- data.frame(  group = c("Male", "Female", "Child"),   value = c(25, 25, 50))  head(df) #>    group value #> 1   Male    25 #> 2 Female    25 #> 3  Child    50   # Basic pie charts # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  ggpie(df, "value", label = "group")   # Reducing margins around the pie chart ggpie(df, "value", label = "group") +  theme( plot.margin = unit(c(-.75,-.75,-.75,-.75),"cm"))    # Change color # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Change fill color by group # set line color to white # Use custom color palette  ggpie(df, "value", label = "group",       fill = "group", color = "white",        palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07") )    # Change label # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Show group names and value as labels labs <- paste0(df$group, " (", df$value, "%)") ggpie(df, "value", label = labs,    fill = "group", color = "white",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))   # Change the position and font color of labels ggpie(df, "value", label = labs,    lab.pos = "in", lab.font = "white",    fill = "group", color = "white",    palette = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))

title: ggpubr General Arguments Description — ggpubr_args
text: data data frame x character string containing name x variable. y character vector containing one variables plot combine logical value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, create multi-panel plot combining plot y variables. merge logical character value. Default FALSE. Used y vector containing multiple variables plot. TRUE, merge multiple y variables plotting area. Allowed values include also "asis" (TRUE) "flip". merge = "flip", y variables used x tick labels x variable used grouping variable. color outline color. fill fill color. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". linetype line types. size Numeric value (e.g.: size = 1). change size points outlines. select character vector specifying items display. remove character vector specifying items remove plot. order character vector specifying order items. add character vector adding another plot element (e.g.: dot plot error bars). Allowed values one combination : "none", "dotplot", "jitter", "boxplot", "point", "mean", "mean_se", "mean_sd", "mean_ci", "mean_range", "median", "median_iqr", "median_mad", "median_range"; see ?desc_statby details. add.params parameters (color, shape, size, fill, linetype) argument 'add'; e.g.: add.params = list(color = "red"). error.plot plot type used visualize error. Allowed values one c("pointrange", "linerange", "crossbar", "errorbar", "upper_errorbar", "lower_errorbar", "upper_pointrange", "lower_pointrange", "upper_linerange", "lower_linerange"). Default value "pointrange" "errorbar". Used add != "none" add contains one "mean_*" "med_*" "*" = sd, se, .... font.label list can contain combination following elements: size (e.g.: 14), style (e.g.: "plain", "bold", "italic", "bold.italic") color (e.g.: "red") labels. example font.label = list(size = 14, face = "bold", color ="red"). specify size style, use font.label = list(size = 14, face = "plain"). title plot main title. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), ....

what: ggpubrplus: 'ggplot2' Based Publication Ready Plots (Extended) — ggpubrplus-package
title: ggpubrplus: 'ggplot2' Based Publication Ready Plots (Extended) — ggpubrplus-package
text: Supplementary compatibility updates ggpubr (Kassambara, 2023), flexible p-value formatting modern R ecosystem support. Modern R ecosystem support (ggplot2 >= 4.0.0, dplyr >= 1.2.0, tidyr >= 1.3.2, R >= 4.1.0) - cited original package. 'ggplot2' package excellent flexible elegant data visualization R. However default generated plots requires formatting can send publication. Furthermore, customize 'ggplot', syntax opaque raises level difficulty researchers advanced R programming skills. 'ggpubrplus' provides easy--use functions creating customizing 'ggplot2'-based publication ready plots. Features include customizable p-value formatting predefined style presets (APA, AMA, NEJM, Lancet, GraphPad) matching journal-specific publication requirements.

title: ggpubrplus: 'ggplot2' Based Publication Ready Plots (Extended) — ggpubrplus-package
text: General resources: ggpubrplus documentation Original ggpubr documentation

title: ggpubrplus: 'ggplot2' Based Publication Ready Plots (Extended) — ggpubrplus-package
text: ggpubrplus provides customizable p-value formatting predefined style presets match different journal publication requirements. Use format_p_value() direct formatting, set p.format.style statistical functions. Available styles: "default", "apa", "nejm", "lancet", "ama", "graphpad", "scientific". See list_p_format_styles() details style.

title: ggpubrplus: 'ggplot2' Based Publication Ready Plots (Extended) — ggpubrplus-package
text: ggpubr.parse_aes logical indicating whether parse aesthetics variables names. Default TRUE. example, want ggpubrplus handle non-standard column names, like -, without parsing, set option FALSE using options(ggpubr.parse_aes = FALSE). ggpubr.null_device function creates appropriate null device. include: cowplot::pdf_null_device, cowplot::png_null_device, cowplot::cairo_null_device cowplot::agg_null_device. Default cowplot::pdf_null_device. used function like as_ggplot(), needs open graphics device render ggplot objects grid graphics objects. function used open null device avoiding display unnecessary blank page calling ggarrange() as_ggplot()
